By Ming Li

Published December 10, 2019

Since 2014, China has issued a number of policies to tackle the air pollution in its capital city, including a ban of coal use in 2017. The air quality in Beijing has improved over the past few years, especially in winter, during which coal heating used to be a major source of pollution in the past.

In terms of health effects, the guideline states that PM2.5 concentration of 10 is the lowest level at which total, cardiopulmonary and lung cancer mortality have been shown to increase with more than 95% confidence in response to long-term exposure to PM2.5.

Beijing was once synonymous with dirty air. But in 2014, the government announced a “war against pollution,” pledging to clean up the dangerous haze hanging over many of China’s major cities. “We will resolutely declare war against pollution as we declared war against poverty,” Premier Li Keqiang announced in front of 3,000 delegates at the National People’s Congress in an address broadcast on state television. The country set strict limits on burning coal and implemented new emissions standards for power plants and heavy industry. It also banned the construction of new coal plants surrounding Beijing and other highly polluted areas and shut down some of the oldest, most polluting plants.

winds contribute to the smog by carrying pollutants from industrialized southern regions.

The sandstorms begin in areas such as Inner Mongolia where overgrazing and deforestation have increased desert areas. Strong winds pick up loose dust and dirt, mixing them with industrial pollution.

Source: Natural Earth Data

Source: The Guardian

Among the 36 detectors distributed in Beijing, the majority are concentrated in the municipal area. Those detectors, built by the local government, have documented Beijing's air pollution level in the past decade.

Source: Beijing Municipal Environmental Monitoring Center

Data showed that all locations have seen the number of pollution days declined from 2015 to 2018. Any day with an average PM2.5 concentration level above 100 is considered as polluted and "very unhealthy" for human beings according to World Health Organization. The number of pollution days have decreased from over 100 to less than 50 in 2018.

Number of pollution days have decreased in different regions in Beijing from 2015 to 2018.

Severe pollution days in 2015

Severe pollution days in 2016

Severe pollution days in 2017

Severe pollution days in 2018

The four most dangerous pollutants that are emitted include: sulfur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen dioxide (NO2).
